xxl.core.relational.cursors
Class MergeSorter

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.sorters.MergeSorter<Tuple>
          xxl.core.relational.cursors.MergeSorter
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<Tuple>, Cursor<Tuple>, MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>
public class MergeSorter
extends MergeSorter<Tuple>
implements MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>

A merge-sort implementation of a sort operator.

This class uses the algorithm of MergeSorter and additionally forwards the metadata. A detailed description of the algorithm is contained in MergeSorter.

In earlier versions of XXL it was possible to hand over a string array instead of an array of indices. To get this functionality, use ResultSets.getColumnIndices(ResultSet, String[]).

Constructor Detail

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator,
                   int blockSize,
                   int objectSize,
                   int memSize,
                   double firstOutputBufferRatio,
                   double outputBufferRatio,
                   double inputBufferRatio,
                   int finalMemSize,
                   double finalInputBufferRatio,
                   Function<Function<?,java.lang.Integer>,? extends Queue<Tuple>> newQueue,
                   Function<java.lang.Object,? extends Queue<Cursor<Tuple>>> newQueuesQueue,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Cursor<Tuple>> queuesQueueComparator,
                   boolean verbose)
Creates a new merge-sorter.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).
blockSize - the size of a block (page).
objectSize - the size of an object in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
firstOutputBufferRatio - the ratio of memory available to the output-buffer during run-creation.
0.0
use only one page for the output buffer and what remains is used for the heap
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the output buffer
outputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the output-buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge).
0.0
use only one page for the output buffer, what remains is used for the merger and the input buffer, inputBufferRatio determines how the remaining memory is distributed between them
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the output buffer
inputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input-buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge).
0.0
use only one page for the input buffer, what remains is used for the merger (maximal fan-in)
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the input buffer
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.
finalInputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input-buffer of the final (online) merge.
0.0
maximum number of inputs (maximal fan-in), i.e., perform the online merge as early as possible
1.0
write the entire data into a final queue, the online "merger" just reads the data from this queue
newQueue - the function newQueue should return a queue, which is used by the algorithm to materialize the internal runs, i.e., this function determines whether the sort operator works on queues based on external storage or in main memory (useful for testing and counting). The function takes two parameterless functions getInputBufferSize and getOutputBufferSize as parameters.
newQueuesQueue - if this function is invoked, the queue, that should contain the queues to be merged, is returned. The function takes an iterator and the comparator queuesQueueComparator as parameters. E.g., 
          new Function<Object, Queue<Tuple>>() {
              public Queue<Tuple> invoke(Object iterator, Object comparator) {
                  return new DynamicHeap<Tuple>((Iterator<Tuple>)iterator, (Comparator<Tuple>)comparator);
              }
          };
The queues contained in the iterator are inserted in the dynamic heap using the given comparator for comparison.
queuesQueueComparator - this comparator determines the next queue used for merging.
verbose - if the verbose flag set to true the merge-sorter displays how the memory was distributed internally. In addition, the number of merges is displayed.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator,
                   int objectSize,
                   int memSize,
                   int finalMemSize)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap and they are compared according their sizes.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).
objectSize - the size of a tuple in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator,
                   int objectSize,
                   int memSize,
                   int finalMemSize,
                   Function<Function<?,java.lang.Integer>,? extends Queue<Tuple>> newQueue,
                   boolean verbose)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queues to be merged are inserted in a dynamic heap and they are compared according their sizes.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).
objectSize - the size of a tuple in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.
newQueue - the function newQueue should return a queue, which is used by the algorithm to materialize the internal runs, i.e., this function determines whether the sort operator works on queues based on external storage or in main memory (useful for testing and counting). The function takes two parameterless functions getInputBufferSize and getOutputBufferSize as parameters.
verbose - if the verbose flag set to true the merge-sorter displays how the memory was distributed internally. In addition, the number of merges is displayed.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   int[] onColumns,
                   boolean[] ascending,
                   int objectSize,
                   int memSize,
                   int finalMemSize)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap. The tuples are compared using a comparator returned by the Tuples.getTupleComparator method. This is the type of constructor that is used in most cases.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
onColumns - an array of column indices identifying the column to be compared: the first column is 1, the second is 2, ...
ascending - an array of boolean values that determines the order (ascending=true/descending=false) for each dimension.
objectSize - the size of a tuple in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   int[] onColumns,
                   boolean[] ascending)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap. The object size is set to 128, the memory size to 12*4096 and the final memory size to 4*4096. The tuples are compared using a comparator returned by the Tuples.getTupleComparator method. This is the type of constructor that is used in most cases.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
onColumns - an array of column indices identifying the column to be compared: the first column is 1, the second is 2, ...
ascending - an array of boolean values that determines the order (ascending=true/descending=false) for each dimension.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap and they are compared according their sizes. The object size is set to 128, the memory size to 12*4096 and the final memory size to 4*4096.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(java.sql.ResultSet resultSet,
                   Function<? super java.sql.ResultSet,? extends Tuple> createTuple,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator,
                   int blockSize,
                   int objectSize,
                   int memSize,
                   double firstOutputBufferRatio,
                   double outputBufferRatio,

                   Function<java.lang.Object,? extends Queue<Cursor<Tuple>>> newQueuesQueue,
                   java.util.Comparator<? super Cursor<Tuple>> queuesQueueComparator,
                   boolean verbose)
Creates a new merge-sorter.

Parameters:
resultSet - the input result set delivering the elements. The result set is wrapped internally to a metadata cursor using ResultSetMetaDataCursor.
createTuple - a function that maps a (row of the) result setet to a tuple. The function gets a result set and maps the current row to a tuple. It is forbidden to call the next, update and similar methods of the result set from inside the function!
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).
blockSize - the size of a block (page).
objectSize - the size of an object in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
firstOutputBufferRatio - the ratio of memory available to the output-buffer during run-creation.
0.0
use only one page for the output buffer and what remains is used for the heap
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the output buffer
outputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the output-buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge).
0.0
use only one page for the output buffer, what remains is used for the merger and the input buffer, inputBufferRatio determines how the remaining memory is distributed between them
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the output buffer
inputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input-buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge).
0.0
use only one page for the input buffer, what remains is used for the merger (maximal fan-in)
1.0
use as much memory as possible for the input buffer
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.
finalInputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input-buffer of the final (online) merge.
0.0
maximum number of inputs (maximal fan-in), i.e., perform the online merge as early as possible
1.0
write the entire data into a final queue, the online "merger" just reads the data from this queue
newQueue - the function newQueue should return a queue, which is used by the algorithm to materialize the internal runs, i.e., this function determines whether the sort operator works on queues based on external storage or in main memory (useful for testing and counting). The function takes two parameterless functions getInputBufferSize and getOutputBufferSize as parameters.
newQueuesQueue - if this function is invoked, the queue, that should contain the queues to be merged, is returned. The function takes an iterator and the comparator queuesQueueComparator as parameters. E.g., 
          new Function<Object, Queue<Tuple>>() {
              public Queue<Tuple> invoke(Object iterator, Object comparator) {
                  return new DynamicHeap<Tuple>((Iterator<Tuple>)iterator, (Comparator<Tuple>)comparator);
              }
          };
The queues contained in the iterator are inserted in the dynamic heap using the given comparator for comparison.
queuesQueueComparator - this comparator determines the next queue used for merging.
verbose - if the verbose flag set to true the merge-sorter displays how the memory was distributed internally. In addition, the number of merges is displayed.

                   java.util.Comparator<? super Tuple> comparator,

Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap and they are compared according their sizes.

Parameters:
resultSet - the input result set delivering the elements. The result set is wrapped internally to a metadata cursor using ResultSetMetaDataCursor.
createTuple - a function that maps a (row of the) result setet to a tuple. The function gets a result set and maps the current row to a tuple. It is forbidden to call the next, update and similar methods of the result set from inside the function!
comparator - the comparator used to compare the tuples in the heap (replacement-selection).
objectSize - the size of a tuple in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the next-phase.

                   Function<? super java.sql.ResultSet,? extends Tuple> createTuple,
                   int[] onColumns,

Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap. The tuples are compared using a comparator returned by the Tuples.getTupleComparator method. This is the type of constructor that is used in most cases.

onColumns - an array of column indices identifying the column to be compared: the first column is 1, the second is 2, ...

memSize - the memory available to the merge-sorter during the open-phase.

MergeSorter

public MergeSorter(java.sql.ResultSet resultSet,
                   Function<? super java.sql.ResultSet,? extends Tuple> createTuple,
                   int[] onColumns,
                   boolean[] ascending)
Creates a new merge-sorter. The parameters inputBufferRatio, finalInputBufferRatio, firstOutputBufferRatio and outputBufferRatio are set to 0.0. That means only one page is reserved for input- and output-buffer and the maximal fan-in is used during the intermediate merges and for the final merge. The queue are given by list-queues, i.e., the intermediate runs are materialized in main memory and they will be inserted in a dynamic heap. The object size is set to 128, the memory size to 12*4096 and the final memory size to 4*4096. The tuples are compared using a comparator returned by the Tuples.getTupleComparator method. This is the type of constructor that is used in most cases.

ascending - an array of boolean values that determines the order (ascending=true/descending=false) for each dimension.
